name: Team Lead
Description:
Our vision is that every child receives one daily meal in their place of education and that all those who have more than they need, share with those who lack even the most basic things. $26.40 is all it costs for us to feed a child for a whole school year.  That is only .13 cents a day.  Currently, we are feeding over 2 million children a day in 20 countries. Our idea is a simple one that works. We provide one nutritious daily meal in a place of learning in order to attract chronically poor children into the classroom, where they receive an education that can, in the future, be their ladder out of poverty. Every child deserves an education and enough to eat.

Our work is mainly carried out by our wonderful army of Community Ambassadors who volunteer by contributing in all sorts of different ways. But we’re always in need of more help as the need is great! The more Community Ambassadors we can partner with, the more hungry children we can reach.
We have a range of fulfilling and fun opportunities to help you raise awareness of the work of Mary’s Meals in your local area as a Team Lead.
Deciding to join our movement and become a Team Lead, you will be leading a group of passionate volunteers, you will join us as we grow our movement through local groups to motivate and inspire people in your local community to support our work.
As a valued member of the Mary’s Meals family, in this role as Team Lead you will motivate, inspire, and build your team of Community Ambassadors to share the work of Mary’s Meals. We provide you with support, resources and training to ensure your success!
We have a range of activities that your group of Community Ambassadors can do from the comfort of their own home during this time of local restrictions. These include:

Promoting our work on social media.
Giving talks to local groups.
Hosting community engagement events such as film screenings about Mary's Meals’ work. 
 Meeting with other local Mary’s Meals Community Ambassadors in your community.
Hosting fun virtual or in person events like game nights.

As restrictions change across Canada, other key activities may include:

 Sharing our story with local community organizations, schools, churches, and faith groups. 
Organizing fundraising events in your local area – bottle drives, bake sales, car wash, clothing drive etc.
Promoting Mary’s Meals’ fundraising campaigns in your community. 
Distributing and displaying promotional materials.
Helping to generate support from businesses in your local area. 

"I chose to be a community ambassador at Mary's Meals Canada because their values and goals closely aligned with my own. Mary's Meals believes that every child deserves an education on a full stomach. This ensures each child is at their best and able to learn as much as they can. There might be many barriers to education, but Mary's Meals is doing their best to ensure food isn't one of them. Because of their transparent use of donations, and a mission statement that sets their organization apart, I am proud to represent Mary's Meals in my community!” - Atif, Community Ambassador, Ontario 
We look forward to partnering together with you!!!

name: non profit -Thrift Store Volunteer
Description:
St. John's Thrift Store shares the common understanding of the value of work as a basic human need. Although both require a certain degree of professionalism in their operation, the place of the person is at the heart of both. Our staff are proof that we are all one. We are proud of the mosaic of hands supporting what we do - helping those in need!

Responsibilities:

Under the general supervision of the Store Manager, our volunteers help with the day to day operations of the Thrift Store. Task include (but are not limited to):
Greet, assist and advise customers around areas of store and/or merchandise
Intake of donations and transport between donation drop off area to receiving area
Sort through donations with a knowledge for store merchandise, donations + mission needs  
Organize overstock in designated storage areas
Label, tag and price merchandise according to price guidelines
Ensure all merchandise is aesthetically displayed 
Replenish and organize merchandise areas on the sales floor as required
Assist cashiers as required
Keep all areas of the store (inventory areas, sales floor, etc.) clean and organized
Support Store Manager where required


Time Commitment:

1 to 2 shifts per week
Minimum commitment of 3 months
Shift times: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9:30 am to 2 pm or 2 to 6:30 pm
We are looking to fill daytime shifts but are flexible and will work with you!


Requirements:

The minimum age to volunteer in Ontario is 13 years; parental/guardian consent is required for those under the age of 18. Where there is interest from youth 13-18 years of age, St. John's Thrift Store may arrange a meeting with parents/guardians to assess the suitability of each individual on a case by case basis.
Volunteers are required to stand, walk and be on their feet for the majority of shifts
Frequent contact with public in a fast-paced and changing work environment, which, at times, may be stressful and/or emotional
Volunteers may be requested to lift and/or move up to 25 pounds
English is an asset
Please note: The work environment characteristics described here are representative of those a volunteer encounters while performing the essential functions of this role. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform essential functions.

 
Onboarding: A mandatory 1.5 hour onboarding session will be provided on-site.

Transportation:

Closest TTC Station: Woodbine (we are 1.5 blocks east of Danforth/Woodbine on the south side)
Paid parking available; Unpaid parking available on local streets in close proximity to the store


Benefits

Support a non-profit and charitable organization  St. John The Compassionate Mission
We are environmentally conscious and believe buying secondhand means you'll be keeping plastic out of landfills and positively contributing to the decrease in worldwide textile demand and subsequent waste; less resources used and wasted.
Gain valuable hands on experience in the retail merchandise and/or customer service sectors
Flexible scheduling
This position can serve as Canadian Work experience
This position can serve as Community Involvement Hours towards completion of the Ontario Secondary School Diploma


We are taking the following measures to keep you and our guests safe during these pandemic times:

Increased cleaning and disinfection of high traffic areas
providing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for employees/volunteers
Increased hand washing for all employees/volunteers
Providing guests with hand sanitizer
Maintaining physical distancing (2m)
Limiting occupancy





How to Apply / Contact



Please email St. John's Thrift Store directly at info@stjohnsmission.org with your resume and one professional references.
Please include "volunteer" in the subject line.

University students and seniors welcome!

Thank you.

Who are we?
Youth Assisting Youth (YAY) pairs at-risk children ages 6-15 with older youth mentors ages 16-29. These mentors provide guidance and support to kids in need of a positive role model. Our goal is to help the children in our community feel more confident in themselves and to give them friends that change their lives for the better!
What will you do?

You will share experiences, skills, and hobbies and inspire a younger youth to help them develop their confidence and independence.
Partake in your favourite hobbies with your mentee! You can play sports or video games, teach them how to draw or play and instrument, or just spend time talking about life.
Mentors will be required to meet with their mentees in person. We also host online programming to keep our community connected, including cooking classes, Kahoot! Trivia Nights, and other exciting events!

What kind of Mentors do we need?


Our kids have a diverse range of interests, so we look for mentors with similar hobbies. Want to connect with a fellow gamer? There’s a mentee for you! Do you enjoy sports, or maybe the arts? There’s a mentee for you too!
Experience with kids, including ones diagnosed with mental illness or learning disabilities, is an asset.
We welcome racialized applicants including Black Canadians, persons with disabilities, people who identify as LGBTQ+, and Indigenous peoples to apply for the position.
We have a
    high need for male mentors across the GTA and York Region, who could be
    positive role-models for younger male youth in a one-on-one setting.
We
    are seeking volunteers that can speak two or more languages; we have a
    high need for mentors that can speak Mandarin, Cantonese, Arabic, and
    Russian.

We are looking for LGBTQ+ young adults in the midtown/downtown area to mentor young LGBTQ+ kids in Toronto.

What are the requirements?


You must be between the ages of 16-29 years of age
You must be able to commit to being a mentor for at least a full year, and can spend 3 hours of your week with your mentee (hours must be done concurrently).
You must be able to provide 2 Canadian professional references (employers, volunteer supervisors, teachers/professors, etc.)

General Support staff and volunteers are the backbone of our centre! With thousands of animals being cared for at Toronto Wildlife Centre each year, a tremendous amount of resources are dedicated to both maintaining the upkeep of the facility and ensuring that supplies are clean and readily accessible for the Wildlife Rehabilitation Team. Volunteers who successfully meet the minimum commitment in this role and demonstrate reliability, dedication and responsibility will also be strongly considered for other volunteer roles at TWC!

- Help maintain the cleanliness of the wildlife kitchen, hallways, hospital and rehabilitation rooms. 
- Wash linens used by patients
- Fold and organize clean laundry for patient use
- Wash and sanitize patient caging, enrichment items and other housing supplies
- Ensure that appropriate caging and supplies are organized and are ready for wild patients

Time Commitment
General Support volunteers are asked to commit to a minimum of one 4 hour shift per week. Standard shift times are 9-1pm or 1-5pm, though there is some flexibility if needed (between the hours of 9-5pm). Volunteers are encouraged to make a minimum 3 month commitment to this role, but we are also able to accommodate shorter commitment periods (i.e. 40 hours of community service for High School students)

- 15 years of age or older
- Interest in and respect for the unique needs of wildlife
- Experience with cleaning, organization and/or facility maintenance is a great asset.
- Comfortable with physical work including bending, lifting, and carrying items such as kennel cabs (up to 40lbs)
- Reliable, responsible and punctual
- Up-to-date tetanus vaccination mandatory
- Minimum of 2 doses of COVID-19 vaccination mandatory for all in-person roles
- Non-profit volunteer experience is an asset
Training
General Support volunteers are trained and supervised by General Support staff in-house over their first few shifts.
There is a $25 training fee associated with this position which helps to cover staff time and training resources, volunteers will receive a nametag and volunteer t-shirt upon payment.
 
COVID-19 protocols
 Volunteers are asked to wear masks at all times and put on any other essential PPE if working in close proximity to others. PPE such as masks, face shields, disposable gloves and hand sanitizer are well stocked and readily available for all volunteers. Volunteers must perform a self-assessment for symptoms prior to each shift and are asked to stay home at get tested for COVID if any symptoms are present. We ask that a negative test result be received PRIOR to returning to the volunteer position. Toronto Wildlife Centre is closely abiding by all public health recommendations and protocols. Volunteers are encouraged to let staff or supervisors know if they have any questions, comments or concerns relating to these protocols and their safety while volunteering.
